articles.headline: Illegal Immigrants Line Up by Thousands for Deportation Deferrals
articles.snippet: People who arrived in the United States as children and wish to stay lined up for blocks in several cities on the first day to apply for deportation deferrals and work permits.
articles.abstract: People who arrived in the United States as children and wish to stay lined up for blocks in several cities on the first day to apply for deportation deferrals and work permits.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Tens of thousands of young illegal immigrants waited excitedly in lines as long as a mile and thronged to information sessions across the country on Wednesday, the first day that a federal immigration agency began accepting applications for deportation deferrals that include permits to work legally.

articles.headline: Ratification of Union’s Deal With Caterpillar May Face Difficulties
articles.snippet: The accord would end a three-and-a-half-month walkout in Joliet, Ill., but local union leaders called for its rejection.
articles.abstract: The accord would end a three-and-a-half-month walkout in Joliet, Ill., but local union leaders called for its rejection.
articles.lead_paragraph: Caterpillar and the International Association of Machinists said on Wednesday that they had reached a tentative six-year settlement that could end a 15-week strike at the company’s hydraulics parts plant in Joliet, Ill.

articles.headline: Despite Alarm by U.S., Europe Lets Hezbollah Operate Openly
articles.snippet: Washington and Jerusalem insist Hezbollah is a resurgent terrorist group with Iranian backing, but the European Union treats it as a Lebanese social and political movement.
articles.abstract: Washington and Jerusalem insist Hezbollah is a resurgent terrorist group with Iranian backing, but the European Union treats it as a Lebanese social and political movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As American officials sound the alarm over what they call a resurgent threat from the Shiite militant group Hezbollah, thousands of its members and supporters operate with few restrictions in Europe, raising money that is funneled to the group’s leadership in Lebanon.

articles.headline: Johnson & Johnson to Remove Formaldehyde From Products
articles.snippet: The announcement extended the company’s program to remove certain ingredients from baby products to include adult products.
articles.abstract: The announcement extended the company’s program to remove certain ingredients from baby products to include adult products.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson, which makes a range of personal care products like baby shampoo, acne cream and antiwrinkle lotion, announced plans Wednesday to remove a host of potentially harmful chemicals, like formaldehyde, from its line of consumer products by the end of 2015, becoming the first major consumer products company to make such a widespread commitment.

articles.headline: Muni Bonds Not as Safe as Thought
articles.snippet: Municipal bonds are widely seen as one of the safest investments, but this belief is based on records for a narrow slice of the market, according to new research.
articles.abstract: Municipal bonds are widely seen as one of the safest investments, but this belief is based on records for a narrow slice of the market, according to new research.
articles.lead_paragraph: Municipal bonds, widely seen as one of the safest investments, actually default more often than most people realize, according to research issued Wednesday by economists at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

articles.headline: No Criminal Case Is Likely in Loss at MF Global
articles.snippet: Investigators are expected to conclude that sloppiness, not criminal intent, was the main driver behind the disappearance of customer money.
articles.abstract: Investigators are expected to conclude that sloppiness, not criminal intent, was the main driver behind the disappearance of customer money.
articles.lead_paragraph: A criminal investigation into the collapse of the brokerage firm MF Global and the disappearance of about $1 billion in customer money is now heading into its final stage without charges expected against any top executives.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Years After Haiti Quake, Safe Housing Is a Dream for Many
articles.snippet: Two and a half years after the earthquake, the pressing need for safe, stable housing for all displaced people in Haiti remains unmet, despite billions of dollars in reconstruction aid.
articles.abstract: Two and a half years after the earthquake, the pressing need for safe, stable housing for all displaced people in Haiti remains unmet, despite billions of dollars in reconstruction aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Since the earthquake of Jan. 12, 2010, a scrappy 12-year-old boy named Givenson Fanfan has been sleeping on the rock-hard floor of a tent pitched in a fetid camp dominated by a 50-foot tower of trash. He dreams of a bed.

articles.headline: Choice of Paul Ryan Shifts the Focus From Economy to Ideology
articles.snippet: For both contenders in the presidential race, winning over the small group of undecided voters seems less important than appealing to the base.
articles.abstract: For both contenders in the presidential race, winning over the small group of undecided voters seems less important than appealing to the base.
articles.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Four years ago, John Brooks cast his ballot for Barack Obama, becoming one of the voters won over by his promise for changing Washington. This time, he had been undecided, but he said Mitt Romney made his decision easier by placing Representative Paul D. Ryan on the Republican ticket.

articles.headline: Facebook Shares Hit New Low as a Lockup Period Ends
articles.snippet: Shares fell sharply amid fears that early investors eligible to offload their stocks would create a surplus on the market.
articles.abstract: Shares fell sharply amid fears that early investors eligible to offload their stocks would create a surplus on the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Facebook slide on Wall Street continued on Friday, as the company’s shares reached new lows a day after early investors became eligible to sell their shares on the market. Shares closed down more than 4 percent, to $19.05, after reaching a low of $19.00 during the day — 50 percent lower than its original offering price of $38 in May.
